content:
Recent development in machine learning and AI, are transforming research entomology and insect ecology. However there are still too few opportunities to learn how to best develop and apply these transformative technologies. To fill this gap, we started the Aarhus Comprehensive Computational Entomology Summer School: a five-day course to learn how to apply state-of-the-art imaging, deep-learning and AI methods to insect ecology and entomology.
Where and when ACCESS-2024 will run in Aarhus, Denmark , from September 30th to October 4th, 2024. The event is in-person. Aarhus University is a highly ranked institution, located in a vibrant city, with several researchers leading the field of computational entomology.
What we offer ‚Ä¢ A series of guest lectures and practical workshops from international experts ‚Ä¢ A project-based learning experience within a multidisciplinary student team (you will be matched with other participants) ‚Ä¢ Free accommodation and food for the selected students Who the course is for ‚Ä¢ Early career researchers (graduate students, PhD and postdocs) ‚Ä¢ Biologists (entomologists, ecologists, etc) wanting to apply computational methods to their fields ‚Ä¢ Data scientists (engineers, physicists, etc) seeking to translate their expertise to study insects How to take part ‚Ä¢ Read the application section ‚Ä¢ Fill the application form

content: Melika is a Ph.D. student at QGG (Aarhus University). She holds a background in Biosystems Engineering and is interested in developing tools to enhance agricultural systems and drive a digital green transition that could make agriculture more sustainable, resilient, and productive. Her Ph.D. project aims to develop novel algorithms and annotation tools for hierarchical classification, which have profound and immediate applications to agriculture and ecology.
title: Melika Baghooee

content:
Quentin, assistant professor in the QGG, in Aarhus University is the Principal Investigator of the DARSA group. His background is both in insect physiology and computational biology.
During his PhD at Imperial College London, in the Gilestro Lab, he built an open-source automatic insect behaviour monitoring platform.
In his Postdoc, at UBC, with the Haney Lab and the PIEE Lab, he developed AI-powered smart traps to monitor insects and study their relationships with plants and microbes in agroecological contexts.
Quentin‚Äôs interests in machine learning and sustainable agriculture led him to start the DARSA Group in Aarhus in September 2022.
title: Quentin Geissmann
